journals.notes: Note: When picking up the Obj, WOLF_STEAL_OBJ_BONUS is added to xp. Ensure to avoid a glitch that allows players to earn more xp than they really deserve.
Could you explain how this could be useful, in regards of teamplay?

Actually this creates more opportunities like giving the objective for a healthier player or so on. Or even, you can give the objective to someone who knows how to do it. I have seen this been pretty useful at times from my past experiences. But if this feature would be created, it would mean that it requires a spam protect of some kind.

-*S

Saukko wrote:
> Actually this creates more opportunities like giving the objective for a healthier player or so on. Or even, you can give the objective to someone who knows how to do it. I have seen this been pretty useful at times from my past experiences. But if this feature would be created, it would mean that it requires a spam protect of some kind.

So the real use would be to give the obj to a teammate because he's got more HP. Does that increase teamplay, or does this decrease teamplay in avoiding to have a medic close to you?

Edit: we had a little chat in the channel. This feature doesn't make sense: if you want to give the obj to a teammate because he has more HP... why not trying to do the obj yourself while the teammate escorts you?

Let's close this ticket.

There are occasionally situations where a player picks up an objective and actually isn't that much of an objective oriented player but helps to achieve the objective in other ways. By this I mean some sort of fragging. What I'm trying to explain is that, would you put your best killer to make an objective when the player who is good at killing could stay in the battlefield and keep killing? Anyway I gave a small example on my first post. You need to see the whole situation in gameplay to justify would the feature be handy or not. Sometimes I have seen people teamkilling own teammates to get the objective. Is that true teamplay then?

But since majority seems to be against the feature, the game shall remain as it is then.

-*S

Don't want to do the obj? Then... don't pick up the obj. Having the objective doesn't prevent you to kill. Beside this, the one player that does the objective is the one that probably be really good at defending himself, since all the opposite team will try to take him down. As far I see it, there is no good reason to implement this feature.

I'd say that it's useful when a wrong guy takes the objective. With this change he wouldn't have to kill himself anymore to drop it.

Also, it could be useful for strategic reasons:
When a player carries objective, he has a huge icon indicating it above his head. After dropping the objective in a safe place near him, he would be able to hide behind boxes, barrels or other small things again (because of no huge icon above him that says "hey guys I'm here") and for example kill the whole enemy team from behind because nobody could notice him.

Just quick examples.

Dragonji wrote:
> I'd say that it's useful when a wrong guy takes the objective. With this change he wouldn't have to kill himself anymore to drop it.

Hmm... define "wrong guy"?

> Also, it could be useful for strategic reasons:
> When a player carries objective, he has a huge icon indicating it above his head. After dropping the objective in a safe place near him, he would be able to hide behind boxes, barrels or other small things again (because of no huge icon above him that says "hey guys I'm here") and for example kill the whole enemy team from behind because nobody could notice him.

I see what you mean here, but the objective is automatically retrieved when it is dropped on the field for about ~30s. This is done to ensure the objective isn't lost in some unattainable places. Not sure if you could really use any kind of strategy here. But maybe we should hide the icons above players' head if the player himself isn't in sight?

Spyhawk wrote:
> Hmm... define "wrong guy"?
A guy that wasn't supposed to take the objective (the strategy was different) or a guy that took the objective by accident and would like to drop it so he can do what he was supposed to do (and not block the objective).

> I see what you mean here, but the objective is automatically retrieved when it is dropped on the field for about ~30s. This is done to ensure the objective isn't lost in some unattainable places. Not sure if you could really use any kind of strategy here.
30 seconds is *a lot* during a match.

>  But maybe we should hide the icons above players' head if the player himself isn't in sight?
Isn't it even bigger gameplay changer?

Dragonji wrote:
> 30 seconds is *a lot* during a match.
True.

> Isn't it even bigger gameplay changer?
I'm asking because I recently fixed an issue related to line of sight (#679). Obviously, you can't see the icon above the head of player when the player isn't in sight (behind a wall, inside a building, etc.), and the icon isn't visible on map either if the player isn't in the line of sight of a friendly coverops. If the player himself is hidden behind some boxes, and isn't visible apart from the objective icon.. wouldn't this be a buggy behavior? This would be a per-client change only, although I don't know if that would be worth implementing.
